title: Arms Length Management of Local Authority Housing: A Consultation Paper
body:
This consultation paper is issued in support of the Government's Housing Policy Statement1 following the Green Paper _Quality and Choice; A decent home for all_. It deals specifically with the proposal that local authorities retaining housing stock should consider separating their strategic role and housing management, and that those authorities which have set up arms length arrangements and demonstrated high standards should qualify for additional resources. Sections 1 to 4 deal with the reasons why Ministers consider that separation is desirable, the form which an arms length body might take, the division of functions between the local authority and the arms length body and the financial arrangements. The remaining sections deal with the additional resources available for authorities setting up arms length arrangements, the proposed criteria for the allocation of those resources and the timetable.

The Department has been helped in working up these proposals by a Technical Advisory Group involving the Local Government Association, the Association of London Government, the Chartered Institute of Housing, HM Treasury and the Audit  
Commission

title: Business Planning for Local Authority Housing with Resource Accounting in Place - A Consultation Paper
body: On 15 December 1998, the Government published a consultation paper proposing a new financial framework for local authority housing based on a form of resource accounting. Following consideration of the responses to consultation, the Government announced on 22 June 1999 that (subject to legislative changes where necessary) a new system would be introduced from 1 April 2001 and that there would be further consultation on a number of detailed issues. This paper deals with one of those, guidance on business planning.
attachment_0_name: Business Planning for Local Authority Housing with Resource Accounting in Place: A Consultation Paper

title: Rent Assessment Panels: financial management and policy review - consultation
body: This consultation paper sets out options which might be considered in a report to Ministers on the role and functions of the Rent Assessment Panels in England, including possible changes to achieve improvements in the quality and efficiency of the services provided through the committees and tribunals drawn from the Panels . It reflects wide ranging discussions held with Presidents, members and staff of the Panels and with others during the first stage of the review.
attachment_0_name: Rent Assessment Panels: financial management and policy review - consultation

title: Residential leasehold reform in England and Wales: the way forward
body:
This document follows the residential leasehold reform consultation paper published in November 1998 and outlines a summary of proposals that the Government has  announced as the way forward. 

The Queen's speech on 17 November 1999 announced the Government's intention to publish a draft Bill in the current session of Parliament. This will provide details of the proposals for Commonhold and leasehold reform and will be available next year. It will provide a further opportunity for consultation on the detail.

body:

title: Fire Service Pensions Review: Consultation Paper
body:
A review of the fire service pension scheme was announced in October 1993. The review began in 1994 but the report of the review, and recommendations, were not published before the general election in May 1997 intervened. Since taking office, Ministers have considered the matter afresh. This consultation document offers the opportunity for the fire service representative organisations to comment on the options now put forward for discussion, based on the extensive work undertaken by the review. Except for certain options to improve the management of ill-health retirement, the consultation document is focused on a possible revised fire service pension scheme applying to new entrants only.

title: Amendments to the Model Code of Conduct for Local Authority Members - Summary of Responses
body:
The Government consulted on a revised code of conduct for local authority members on 22 January 2007. The consultation ended on 9 March 2007. The aim was to consult on the detailed amendments needed to the code of conduct for local councillors, so as to put into effect the commitment given in the Local Government White Paper to introduce:

  * a clearer, simpler and more proportionate code, and
  * amended rules on personal and prejudicial interest to remove the current barriers to councillors speaking up for their constituents, for example on planning and licensing issues, and for public bodies on which they have been appointed to serve.

The consultation attracted 906 responses. A summary of the comments received and the amendments which have been made to the code to reflect the issues raised are provided below.
attachment_0_name: Amendments to the Model Code of Conduct for Local Authority Members - Summary of Consultation Responses
